He watched as she winked at the crowd, then slipped a note into his pocket—an invitation to meet her at midnight near the docks. There, amidst the fog and the scent of saltwater, she outlined her plan: infiltrate the mayor’s gala disguised as servants, document the backroom deals, and expose the rot at the city’s core. Over weeks, their partnership grew into friendship, and then something more. When Cecilia’s exposé finally ran, shaking the city to its foundations, he realized he’d witnessed history—and had fallen hopelessly in love with its author.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Somewhere around the turn of the century he met an enterprising young reporter named Cecilia Marks, who was making a name for herself by getting thrown into prisons in order

responses.text: to investigate the rumored disappearances of political dissidents. Their meeting was an accident of fate, orchestrated by a shared cab ride during a thunderstorm, lightning illuminating their faces as they exchanged wary introductions. Cecilia was fearless—she asked questions no one dared, and she listened harder than most. Together they explored the city’s underbelly, chasing whispers through opium dens and shadowed alleyways, piecing together a puzzle that led straight to the city’s powerful elite. On a rain-soaked night, Cecilia was caught and thrown into a cell, but not before thrusting her notebook into his hands and imploring him to finish her story. He spent sleepless nights decoding her shorthand and following her breadcrumbs of clues. When he finally published her exposé, the city woke to outrage and reform. Cecilia returned, freed by the storm her truth had unleashed, and they met again—not as strangers, but as kindred spirits forged in the crucible of danger and hope.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: It’ll be the l-last thing you d-do.” “Do you make such promises to all the pretty girls you meet?” Nurse Ratched asked.

responses.text:
It’ll be the l-last thing you d-do.”

“Do you make such promises to all the pretty girls you meet?” Nurse Ratched asked, her eyes glinting under the flickering fluorescent lights. The patient, wrists bound to the wheelchair, tried to laugh, but a cough rattled instead. Shadows crawled across the linoleum as the night crept closer.

Nurse Ratched wheeled him down the echoing corridor, humming a lullaby that had no melody. "You know, it’s not often someone threatens me on a Tuesday. Most just cry. Or scream."

He struggled, voice hoarse: “S-save… yourself.”

She tapped his forehead with a gloved finger. “I’m not the one who needs saving.”

A door opened. The room was cold, filled with photographs of smiling faces—patients who’d left, or so she claimed. She unstrapped him, just for a moment, and leaned in close.

“Your threats are sweet,” she whispered, “but my promises are sweeter.”

The lights flickered once more, then went out.

It’ll be the l-last thing you d-do.”

“Do you make such promises to all the pretty girls you meet?” Nurse Ratched asked, her lips twitching in a smile that didn’t reach her eyes. The night shift hummed with the static of failing lights and the distant, hollow thump of a mop bucket in the corridor.

He tried to sit up, tugging at the restraints. “This isn’t a game.”

“Oh, but it is,” she replied. “Every night, new rules. Tonight, you threaten me. Tomorrow, someone else will sing, or weep, or beg. It hardly matters.” She checked his pulse with clinical precision, fingers icy against his skin. “But you, you’re interesting. You still think you have power.”

He swallowed. “Someone will come for me.”

Nurse Ratched leaned closer, her voice a whisper. “No one ever does.”

Outside, thunder rolled, and the ward seemed to shrink around them. She patted his shoulder, then walked away, humming a lullaby he almost remembered from childhood.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: It’ll be the l-last thing you d-do.” “Do you make such promises to all the pretty girls you meet?” Nurse Ratched asked.

responses.text:
It’ll be the l-last thing you d-do.”

“Do you make such promises to all the pretty girls you meet?” Nurse Ratched asked, her voice honeyed, but her grip on the tray was iron. The overhead lights flickered as midnight crept through the hospital’s empty halls.

He smiled, a thin line between defiance and fear. “Only the ones who scare me.”

She set the syringe down, needle glinting. “I scare you?”

He nodded. “Terrify.”

Nurse Ratched’s gaze softened, or maybe it was just a trick of the shadows. “Good,” she replied. “Fear keeps you alive.”

He shivered as she approached, her footsteps muffled by linoleum. “But not always,” he muttered.

She paused, considering. “No, not always. But it’s better than hope, isn’t it?”

She pressed the syringe to his arm. “You’ll sleep now. And when you wake, you might just find I’ve kept my promise.”

He closed his eyes and let the darkness in, uncertain whether to be relieved or afraid.

It’ll be the l-last thing you d-do.”

“Do you make such promises to all the pretty girls you meet?” Nurse Ratched asked, arching an eyebrow, the florescent lights glinting off her polished badge. The patient tensed, knuckles white against the coarse blanket.

“I mean it,” he said, voice quivering more from memory than fear. “You c-can’t—”

She tsked, circling his bed like a vulture. “I assure you, darling, I can do quite a lot.” She reached for the chart at the end of his bed, flipping through the pages as if hunting for a weakness. “You’re not the first to bark threats in this ward. They all end the same.”

He swallowed. “How’s that?”

She leaned in, her perfume sharp. “With me tucking you in, and you dreaming sweet, empty dreams.”

The patient closed his eyes, listening to her heels echo down the hall, and wondered if tonight would be different.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: It’ll be the l-last thing you d-do.” “Do you make such promises to all the pretty girls you meet?” Nurse Ratched asked.

responses.text:
It’ll be the l-last thing you d-do.”

“Do you make such promises to all the pretty girls you meet?” Nurse Ratched asked, her silhouette looming in the moonlit window. She slipped the stethoscope from around her neck, letting it dangle between them like a pendulum. The patient’s eyes flickered, torn between terror and fascination.

“I—no, I mean—” he stammered, the words melting in the sterile air.

She leaned in, her voice velvet and venom. “You know, promises are currency in this place. The desperate, the hopeful—they all trade in them. But you, you barter with threats.”

He tried to laugh, but it came out as a cough. “What’s it worth? A threat from a dead man?”

Nurse Ratched drew the curtain closed, shutting out the world. “Sometimes, a threat is just an admission of fear. And sometimes, fear is exactly what I need.”

She left him in darkness, the hush of her footsteps lingering far longer than her words ever would.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so

responses.text: I try not to stare. Instead, I fumble with my suitcase handle, wondering if this youth hostel had been a mistake. The girl—my roommate—stands by the window, sunlight painting gold in her hair, phone pressed to her ear. She glances at me with a quick, shy smile. I look away, pretending to be engrossed in the faded mural behind the reception desk. The parrot guy disappears into the stairwell, leaving behind a faint whiff of incense. I can hear the city outside: horns, laughter, the clatter of skateboards on concrete. My heart thuds with nerves and anticipation. I don’t know whether to introduce myself, unpack, or just bolt for the nearest Pret. But then she speaks, her voice low and warm. 'Hi. I’m Rowan. Sorry about the mess—I unpack like a tornado.' The tension in my shoulders eases, and I find myself smiling back. Maybe, I think, this weekend will be stranger—and better—than I’d imagined.

I barely register him. My nerves are too frayed; I’m still stuck on the thought of the girl I’d be sharing with—distractingly beautiful, luminous in the fluorescent hostel light. I drag my bag past a group of tourists and the parrot man, who mutters something in French to his companion, and climb the staircase to the fourth floor. The corridors smell of cheap detergent and spilled cider. My room is at the end, the door ajar. Inside, she’s sitting cross-legged on the windowsill, sketchbook open, a constellation of colored pencils at her feet. She looks up, startled. 'Hi,' she says, her accent hard to place. 'You must be Jamie.' I nod, swallowing my fear. The parrot squawks from the hall. For a moment, our eyes meet. London, suddenly, feels much too small for the both of us. But I step inside, anyway, ready to find out what happens next.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so

responses.text: I don’t give him a second glance. The city is a kaleidoscope of oddities, and my mind is already racing with questions about my new roommate. What would we talk about? Would she notice my nervous fidgeting? A cab screeches past outside. I climb the narrow stairwell to our floor, my suitcase thumping behind me. At the door, I pause, hand trembling. Inside, she’s draped across her bunk, reading a dog-eared copy of something I can’t quite see. Her hair catches the light, copper and wild. She glances up, eyes meeting mine with a mixture of amusement and curiosity. 'Rough journey?' she asks, her voice soft but edged with mischief. I nod, suddenly aware of my rumpled shirt and flushed cheeks. The city’s noise fades, replaced by the thrum of possibility. Maybe, I think, this won’t be so bad after all.

Nobody so much as blinks. I try to act casual, wrestling my duffel onto my shoulder and squeezing past a group of teenagers in neon rave attire. The hostel’s lobby is a blur of color and chatter. I spot the girl by the vending machine, pulling a strand of hair behind her ear, her beauty so effortless it makes my stomach lurch. The parrot man is talking to the receptionist about a room with a good view for his 'assistant.' I stifle a laugh. The girl glances over and catches my eye. She smiles—tiny, uncertain, but genuine. I wave, nearly dropping my bag. London feels monstrous and magical all at once. Maybe this weekend I’ll learn to belong here, or at least, to share a room with someone who looks like she stepped out of a magazine.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so

responses.text: I try to squeeze past the man and his parrot, muttering an apology, but he doesn’t seem to notice—he’s too busy whispering secrets into the bird’s ear. The city pulses around us: street buskers play jazz on battered trumpets, a hen party in matching pink sashes giggles by, and somewhere down the block a bicycle courier weaves through traffic like a fish darting from a net. When I finally reach the hostel, my nerves are shot. I check in, accept the battered keycard, and climb the winding staircase, dread pooling in my stomach. The door to our room is slightly open. I pause, then push it gently. She’s there by the window, sunlight painting her silhouette in gold. She turns—her eyes bright, her smile careful. I feel like an amateur actor about to walk on stage with a star. 'Hi,' she says, her voice not quite matching her poise. Outside, a siren wails, and inside, I wonder if I’ll ever feel like I belong in this city—or this room.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground.

responses.text: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. For a moment, there was only the sound of his own blood roaring in his ears. The world spun in dizzying spirals. He tried to move, to lift his head, but a heavy boot pinned him in place. Voices swirled above him, muffled, warping into incomprehensible echoes. Someone rifled through his pockets, a harsh laugh punctuating the violation. His fingers twitched. He forced them to curl into the cool dirt, searching for something—anything—to anchor him. A memory flickered: his sister’s smile as she handed him the silver locket, her whispered promise that he’d always find his way home. Now, as the footsteps receded, he clung to that memory, the hard edges of the locket digging into his palm. Slowly, the pain receded enough for him to rise, unsteady but determined. He staggered to his feet, blood trickling from his brow, and limped toward the distant lights. They hadn’t taken everything. He still had hope—and vengeance burning quietly in his chest.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. Colors swirled in front of his eyes, but he was dimly aware of boots crunching on gravel, voices raised in anger and fear. He tried to rise, but the world spun, his limbs heavy as lead. He heard a ragged breath—his own, he realized—and then a sharp pain as someone grabbed the collar of his jacket, hauling him up. “You picked the wrong alley,” a voice hissed. He tasted blood, metallic and hot, and stared up at the blurred face looming above. With a desperate lurch, he twisted free, stumbling backward into the darkness. He crashed into a pile of cardboard boxes, sending them tumbling. Sirens wailed faintly in the distance. He crawled, dragging himself behind a dumpster, heart pounding. The footsteps faded. He waited, trembling, until the night was silent once more. Only then did he let himself cry—just for a moment—before wiping his face and standing, battered but alive, determined to find his way out of the shadows.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground.

responses.text: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. The alley spun around him, neon signs melting into a kaleidoscope of color and pain. He tasted copper and realized it was his own blood, thick on his tongue. Above him, the shadows shifted, resolving into the silhouette of a woman in a red coat. She knelt, her gloved hands gentle as they searched his jacket. "You really should have handed it over," she murmured, retrieving the small glass vial from his inner pocket. "But I admire your stubbornness." The world threatened to slip away, but he grasped at consciousness. "You... have no idea what you've done," he whispered. She smiled, sharp as a knife. "On the contrary, that's exactly the point." Her footsteps echoed away as he faded, the vial—and the fate of the city—no longer in his hands.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. Rain splattered on the pavement around him, pooling in the cracks and crevices. Through the haze of pain, he heard the hurried retreat of footsteps—his assailant vanishing into the night. He tried to remember why he’d been here, in this forgotten corner of the city, but the memory danced just out of reach. Something hard pressed into his side. With shaking fingers, he pulled a crumpled photograph from his pocket—a smiling woman with a dimpled grin. That was it. Her. He forced himself up, one hand bracing against the cold, wet wall. Every movement sent shockwaves through his skull, but he staggered forward, driven by the image in his hand. The night was thick with secrets, and he was determined to uncover them, no matter how many times he fell.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground.

responses.text: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. He landed amid a tangle of wildflowers and broken glass, senses awash with the smell of rain and earth. For a heartbeat, the world paused: droplets hung in the air like tiny diamonds, and the distant song of a nightingale pierced the silence. In the haze, he saw the outline of a fox standing just beyond the alley’s edge, eyes glinting with impossible knowing. As his assailant’s laughter faded, the fox approached, tail trailing stardust. It pressed its nose to his forehead and whispered, in a voice both ancient and new, “You must wake, or you will be lost.” With effort, he blinked, and the world bent around him. He rose, pain blossoming in his skull, and found the alley transformed—a corridor of wild green, the city’s harshness softened by moss. The fox waited, patient. He followed, each step pulling him further from the violence of the night and deeper into a world where wounds healed, and second chances grew wild as weeds.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Most marionettes are fussy and clattery.

responses.text: Most marionettes are fussy and clattery. But in the attic of 32 Willow Lane, there was one who moved with the grace of a drifting feather. Her name was Eloise, and she had never performed on stage. Her wooden limbs were soft from years of dust, her strings tangled into gentle knots that cradled her like a hammock. Every night, when moonlight spilled through the cracked window, Eloise would stir. She danced for the dust motes, gliding across the rafters in perfect silence. She envied the other marionettes their noisy exuberance, but she cherished her quiet, private ballet. One evening, when a storm rattled the house, a gust swept open the attic door. Eloise was swept downstairs, landing softly before a lonely child. The child smiled, picked her up, and Eloise, for the first time, danced not for herself, but for a friend. Her silence was no longer lonely; it was magical.

Most marionettes are fussy and clattery. They jangle in their boxes and argue with their tangled strings. But not Jasper. Jasper was a marionette who longed for stillness. He would sit in the toy shop window, watching the world go by, wishing he could just rest without the threat of sudden motion. One windy afternoon, a stray cat slipped through the door and leaped onto the display. The other marionettes clacked and squeaked in alarm, but Jasper remained perfectly calm. The cat, curious, pawed at his strings, and Jasper’s wooden head nodded slowly, as if in greeting. The shopkeeper entered and saw the cat and Jasper, unmoved. He chuckled, "Finally, a marionette with composure!" From that day on, Jasper was displayed alone in the quietest corner, where he could watch the world in peace, content to be the calm among the chaos.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Most marionettes are fussy and clattery.

responses.text: Most marionettes are fussy and clattery. But one, named Pip, was neither. Crafted from the smoothest birch and strung with the softest thread, Pip moved with an uncanny quietude. The other marionettes teased him, claimed he wasn’t lively enough for the puppet master’s grand shows. One autumn night, as a storm raged and the theater shook, a gust of wind sent the marionettes tumbling from their shelf. Strings tangled, limbs twisted, chaos reigned. Only Pip, perfectly poised, landed upright. When the puppet master arrived, he found Pip alone, untouched amid the mess. Impressed by Pip’s resilience, he chose Pip for the lead in the next performance. Under the stage lights, Pip’s gentle movements mesmerized the audience. The applause thundered, and for the first time, Pip felt proud of his quiet nature. The other marionettes learned that sometimes, stillness could be just as powerful as sound.

Most marionettes are fussy and clattery. Their wooden knees knock together, and their strings twist in endless arguments. But in the back of the old puppet shop, a marionette named Willow sat quietly, her painted eyes always gazing at the rain. She never joined the others’ commotion, nor did she crave the attention of passing customers. One evening, as twilight deepened and the shop emptied, a little girl wandered in, drawn by the hush. She found Willow and picked her up gently. The marionette’s silence seemed to speak volumes. The girl smiled and asked, “Would you like to come home with me?” From that day, Willow left behind the racket, finding peace in the gentle hands of someone who understood her quiet heart.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Most marionettes are fussy and clattery.

responses.text: Most marionettes are fussy and clattery. But not the one carved from driftwood and midnight, whose name nobody dared to utter. In the cobwebbed shadows behind the theater’s velvet curtains, this marionette would only move when the moon was hidden and the wind held its breath. On such nights, its joints creaked not with noise, but with secrets—old tales whispered into its grain by salt and shadow. One evening, a desperate puppeteer, having lost his voice, discovered the silent marionette and, with trembling hands, pulled its strings. The marionette’s performance was wordless yet hauntingly vivid; the audience wept without knowing why. Afterward, the marionette returned to darkness, unseen but never forgotten, and some say the silence of its dance lingers, echoing in the hush just before dawn.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: It was only real with me.

responses.text: It was only real with me. The world outside shimmered with the thin glaze of possibility—real enough to touch, but never to enter. My apartment, with its peeling wallpaper and persistent scent of cardamom, was the only place where reality felt like something I could trust. There, shadows stretched predictably across the floor at dusk, and the hum of the refrigerator never shifted into strange keys. Outside, people’s faces seemed to blur at the edges, their words melting before they could be understood. But inside, my cat would knead my chest, purrs vibrating in a language I didn’t need to translate. It was only real with me—until the rainstorm last Thursday, when a knock at the door fractured the fragile boundary. A woman, soaked and shaking, stared at me with eyes almost familiar. "You see it, too," she whispered. The world outside lurched, and for the first time, I wondered if I’d been wrong about what was real at all.

It was only real with me. The moment Aaron vanished into the mirror, I knew no one else would believe it. The glass rippled, swallowing him whole, and then stilled, reflecting only my wide, terrified eyes. I pressed my palms to the cold surface, desperate for any sign, any proof, but the glass yielded nothing. That night, I tried to explain to Mom, but she shook her head and told me to stop making up stories. The next morning, Aaron’s room was empty—no clothes, no soccer trophies, no pictures on the wall. When I asked about him, everyone looked at me blankly. It was as if he’d never existed. But in the quiet hours, when the moonlight crept across the floor, I could hear Aaron’s voice echoing softly from the mirror, calling out for me. I was the only one who could remember, the only one who knew the truth. It was only real with me.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: It was only real with me.

responses.text: It was only real with me. The old toy train, with its chipped blue paint and rusted wheels, came alive every midnight, chugging around my bedroom with a soft, persistent whistle. I tried to show my father, dragging him out of bed at 12:03, but the train would always be stone-still, gathering dust by the window. My sister laughed, teasing me with ghost stories, but I knew the truth. Every night, I’d sit cross-legged on my rug as carriages clattered and tracks appeared out of nowhere, winding through mountains of laundry and tunnels made from books. Sometimes, the conductor—a mouse in a brass-buttoned coat—would tip his hat and invite me aboard. I never dared. Years later, when the house was empty and the train silent, I’d find toy tracks pressed into the carpet and a faint scent of coal lingering in the air. I still wonder if it was only real with me, or if some magic survives in old toys and sleepless nights.

It was only real with me. The summer I turned seventeen, I found the hidden door behind the garden shed. The hinges creaked as I pushed it open, stepping into a world woven from lavender and silver mist. There were trees that sang lullabies and rivers that shimmered with laughter. I spent hours there, talking with the foxes who wore spectacles and listening to the wind recite poetry. Each evening, I’d return to my family, sun-warmed and secretive, unable to explain why my eyes sparkled or my dreams grew wild. When I brought my brother to the shed, the door was gone—only tangled ivy and a broken rake remained. He shrugged and wandered off, unconcerned. But I knew the world was still there, waiting for me alone. Sometimes, under a violet sky, I can still hear the trees singing my name.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: It was only real with me.

responses.text: It was only real with me. The moment I closed my eyes, the world transformed: the cracked pavement of my city block softened into lush jungle, and the distant wail of sirens became the call of unseen birds. My hands, so ordinary just moments before, shimmered with faint threads of silver, and the air pulsed with colors that had no names. I built a palace from moonbeams, danced on rivers of ink, and spoke in forgotten tongues to creatures that did not exist—at least, not for anyone else. When I opened my eyes, reality snapped back into place, gray and unyielding. Friends laughed and teachers scolded, and no one noticed the small, secret smile I wore. Only I knew that, with a breath and the closing of my lids, the impossible would bloom again. It was only real with me, and that was enough.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges.

responses.text:
Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges. The corridor pulsed with a sickly green light, each step forward echoing in her ears like the tolling of a distant bell. She gripped the relic tighter, its etched surface hot against her palm. The voices—whispers that had haunted her since she picked up the artifact—grew sharper as she neared the threshold. Beyond the archway, the room simmered with an energy she could almost taste; metallic and sweet, it clung to the roof of her mouth.

She blinked sweat from her eyes and forced her trembling legs to carry her over the threshold. There, in the center of the chamber, the Veil shimmered, thin as mist, separating the living from the ancient. Lore hesitated, the pain in her head now a storm, but she pressed the relic to her chest. The voices crescendoed, then fell silent. The Veil parted. With a step that felt like both surrender and triumph, Lore crossed over, leaving the pain—and her world—behind.

Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges. The fog curled around her ankles, thick as wool, muffling her footsteps as she approached the ancient sycamore. Its roots had broken through the graveled path, twisting toward her like the fingers of a slumbering giant.

She paused and pressed her palm to the bark, feeling a pulse—delicate, rhythmic—beneath the moss. The ache in her skull threatened to overwhelm her, but she focused on the breath, the steady in and out, grounding her. A whisper, soft and insistent, wound through the air: "You’re almost here."

She glanced over her shoulder. The world behind her had faded into shadows and indistinct shapes, the only certainty the tree before her. With a final breath, Lore stepped forward, letting the roots envelop her feet, the pain dissolving into a strange, silvery warmth. The sycamore opened, and she stepped into its heart, where memories not her own swirled in the quiet, waiting for her to claim them.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges.

responses.text:
Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges. The staircase spiraled before her, each riser groaning under the shifting weight of time. She pressed a trembling hand to the cool stone wall, feeling the thrum of something alive within it. Her footsteps echoed, drawing the attention of unseen things lurking in the shadows above.

At the landing, the air thickened. A shadow detached itself from the gloom, voice crackling like static: “Why have you come?” Lore’s vision swam, bright pinpricks shooting behind her eyes, but she forced herself upright. “I’m here for the truth,” she croaked, each word costing her. The shadow seemed to nod, drifting aside to reveal a battered door. Lore reached for the handle, energy spent, and the pain receded for one glorious, terrifying instant. What waited beyond was unknown, but she stepped forward, determined to meet it on her own terms.

Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges. Her hands fumbled for the glass vial in her coat pocket, the one she’d promised never to use. But the flickering lights in the tunnel ahead were growing brighter, and the thrum of voices—distant but insistent—demanded she hurry.

She uncorked the vial. The liquid inside shimmered with impossible colors. Lore hesitated only a moment before drinking. The world shifted, pain replaced by a ringing clarity that swept her forward. She stumbled into the chamber, where a circle of masked figures awaited, silent save for their synchronized breathing. In the center, the stone altar pulsed with energy. Lore exhaled, squared her shoulders, and approached—ready at last to face what she’d come for, consequences be damned.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges.

responses.text: Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges. The scent of ozone and burnt feathers filled the air, remnants of the rift that shimmered just ahead. Her shadow stretched unnaturally long along the cracked tiles, twisting as if it had a will of its own. She gritted her teeth and advanced, each footstep carrying her deeper into the aftermath of the storm. On the far side of the chamber, a creature hunched over a nest of shattered mirrors, its wings flickering between substance and smoke. It raised its head, golden eyes meeting hers with a gaze both ancient and pleading. Lore exhaled, letting the pain become a dull hum. She reached into her satchel and withdrew a silver feather—the key to the bargain she’d made. The creature’s cry echoed through the void as she stepped forward, offering salvation or surrender; in that moment, Lore understood that her agony was merely the price of passage into a world forever changed.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground.

responses.text: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. For a moment, the world spun in a whirl of black and red. The cold pavement pressed against his cheek, rough and wet from the recent rain. Above, voices—sharp, panicked, unfamiliar—drifted in and out, like distant radio static. Someone shouted his name, but it sounded wrong, distorted. He tried to move, to speak, but his limbs felt like sacks of wet sand. A metallic taste filled his mouth. Somewhere far off, the screech of tires and the slam of a car door. Shadows flickered across his vision; a boot nudged his ribs, then retreated. The world dimmed further. He remembered the photograph in his wallet, the promise he’d made just before leaving the apartment. He clung to that, a single thread of memory, as the darkness closed in, swallowing voices, footsteps, rain, and regret. When he finally woke, blinking against the harsh hospital lights, everything had changed, including him.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. For a heartbeat, silence reigned, broken only by the rasp of his own breath. Above him, the neon sign flickered, painting the alley in lurid pink and blue. The man who had hit him—a giant in a rain-soaked trench coat—stood over him, breathing heavily. "Stay down," the stranger growled. But even as pain blossomed in his skull, adrenaline surged. He fumbled in his pocket, fingers closing around the cool, reassuring weight of the locket. The one she’d given him—the one they all wanted. He forced himself upright, vision swimming. The alley spun. He staggered, clutching the locket to his chest, and ran. Footsteps thundered behind. He didn’t look back. He wouldn’t let them have it. Not tonight. Not ever.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground.

responses.text: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. The world fractured into shards of sound and color—sirens wailing, footsteps receding, the distant echo of laughter. His body felt impossibly heavy, fused with the cold cement beneath him. He tried to remember where he was, why he was here, but images flickered and vanished: a red scarf, a flash of silver, the knowing smile of a stranger. Through the fog, he heard a whisper, close to his ear: "This isn't the end." He wanted to answer, to protest, but his jaw wouldn't move. Instead, he drifted, weightless, carried by the memory of the promise he'd made. When consciousness returned, he was somewhere else—a dim room, the hum of machines. Above him, a pair of eyes watched, unblinking. "Welcome back," came the voice, gentler now. "You still have work to do."

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. Colors blurred, and a high-pitched ringing drowned out the world. He tried to focus, to anchor himself, but the edges of his vision grew dark. Somewhere above, rain began to fall, each drop a cold needle on his skin. Was this how it ended? The mission, the secrets, all unraveling with a single blow. Through the haze, he felt hands searching his pockets, rough and impatient. He wanted to fight, to scream, but his body refused to respond. Then, just before the darkness claimed him, a pair of boots stopped beside his head. "You should have stayed out of it," a voice muttered. "But you never listen." Everything faded. Hours later, he woke in a place he didn’t recognize, a coded message clenched in his fist.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground.

responses.text: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. The world spun away, replaced by a kaleidoscope of memories: childhood summers in the backyard, his mother’s laughter, the scent of cinnamon rolls baking on Sundays. But the memories were interrupted by the low hum of voices nearby, urgent and unfamiliar. He felt the cold press of concrete against his cheek, a dull ache radiating from his skull. Above him, rain began to fall, mingling with the sticky warmth trickling from his wound. Fingers brushed his jacket, searching, then withdrew. A single coin rolled from his pocket, spinning in a shallow puddle, catching the thin glow of a streetlamp. As consciousness ebbed and flowed, he heard a gentle tune—someone was whistling, eerily calm. With monumental effort, he cracked open one eye to see a stranger crouched beside him, a gloved hand offering the coin back. "Not your night, is it?" the stranger murmured, voice soft, almost kind. Then everything faded, and the world became memory once more.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so

responses.text:
The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so I barely register the oddities. We’re in a rented flat above a bakery, the air seeping with warm sourdough and the metallic tang of the city. My flatmate, Evie, has already claimed the window bed. Her suitcase is monogrammed, her hair is perfect, and she’s scrolling through her phone like she’s searching for treasure. 

“Hi,” I say, awkwardly setting down my battered duffel. She glances up, appraising me as if I’m a misdelivered parcel. 

“Hey,” she replies, voice smooth, accent indeterminate. The parrot squawks from the street below, startling us both. For a moment, we laugh, and the tension breaks. Maybe, I think, the city isn’t so strange after all. But then Evie’s phone buzzes, her smile vanishes, and she slips out of the room with a final, unreadable look. I wonder what secrets she’s brought with her—besides her impossible beauty.

The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so who am I to judge? I shift my backpack nervously as I ring the bell. The door swings open. She stands there, sunlight catching the copper in her hair, a faint freckle constellation across her nose. 

“Hi, you must be Jamie?” she asks. 

“Yes,” I stammer, aware of my own reflection in the glass—awkward, uncertain. We shake hands. 

From the hallway, I glimpse a painting of a fox in a bowler hat and a spiral staircase with shoes neatly lined up by size. Upstairs, my new room is tiny, but the window opens onto a tangle of city sounds: a violinist playing Oasis, a busker’s off-key harmonica, the parrot cackling somewhere below. 

As I unpack, I remind myself: London is for beginnings. Still, I can’t help wondering what it will mean to live in the orbit of someone who seems made of light.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so

responses.text:
The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so I suppose anything goes. I trudge up the steps to the hostel, dragging my suitcase behind me. The receptionist barely looks up as I check in, her focus fixed on a battered paperback. 

Room 207 is at the end of a corridor that smells of bleach and something floral. I knock, then open the door. She’s sitting on the windowsill, legs crossed, sketchbook on her knees. Her hair is a waterfall of dark curls, catching the pale afternoon light. She glances at me, eyes bright, and smiles—a quick, lopsided grin that makes me forget the city’s noise for a moment. 

“Hi,” she says, closing her book. “I’m Lila.”

I nod, suddenly shy. “I’m Ben.”

The parrot squawks outside, as if on cue. Lila laughs, and just like that, the distance between us shrinks, and I convince myself maybe London won’t swallow me whole after all.

The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so I try not to stare. I find the right building, hands sweaty on my suitcase handle, and buzz the flat. 

She opens the door with a practiced ease, as if she’s expecting someone far more interesting. Her voice is soft, but she moves with the kind of confidence that makes the hallway seem smaller. 

We exchange names, mine catching on my tongue, hers—Isobel—rolling effortlessly off hers. In the cramped kitchen we make awkward tea, both pretending not to notice the way the city roars through the open window. 

She tells me she’s a dancer, here for auditions. I mumble about starting a new job. The parrot man’s laughter echoes up from the street, and Isobel smiles. "London’s full of characters," she says. 

I want to ask if she means people like him, or like us. But instead, I nod, clutching my mug, and wonder what kind of story I’ve just stepped into.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so

responses.text:
The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so I don’t bother to question it. Instead, I grip my battered suitcase and step into the narrow, twisting alley that promises shortcuts and secrets. The flat is on the fourth floor above a Vietnamese bakery and there’s no lift, so by the time I arrive, breathless, she’s already there—barefoot, painting her toenails a shade of blue I’ve never seen before. She looks up, smiles, and taps the brush against the rim. 

“Did you see the parrot?” she asks, as if this is the most important question. 

I nod, still catching my breath. 

“That’s Edgar. He’s not real, but the man is convinced he is. London’s like that—half make-believe, half memory.”

She gestures at the only other bed, and I toss my suitcase down, wondering if I’ll ever truly belong in a place where reality is this flexible, and beauty is just another puzzle to solve.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: If anyone saw her with Bastian and grass stains on her skirt, the conclusion they drew would have nothing to do with that kind of riding.

responses.text: If anyone saw her with Bastian and grass stains on her skirt, the conclusion they drew would have nothing to do with that kind of riding. In the late afternoon sun, the two of them had been racing their old bikes down the abandoned golf course behind the school, chasing the ghostly echoes of summers past. Bastian would yell, "Last one down the hill buys ice cream!" and she would pedal so hard her knees ached. When her bike hit a rut, she flew, landing with a thud and a laugh, grass streaking across her shins and dress. Bastian was at her side in a heartbeat, grinning wide, his own jeans torn at the knee. They lay back on the slope, hearts pounding, inventing stories about cloud castles. If anyone saw them now, they'd assume whispers and secrets, but the truth was simpler: two friends, out of breath, out of time, stealing one last childhood moment before everything changed. But she knew, deep down, that these grass stains would fade, but the memory would stick, green and wild, long after the summer was gone.

If anyone saw her with Bastian and grass stains on her skirt, the conclusion they drew would have nothing to do with that kind of riding. She had never even sat on a horse before, but somehow Bastian convinced her that a wheelbarrow race was the only proper way to settle their argument. The debate—over who could recite more digits of pi—had spilled onto the quad, drawing a small crowd of onlookers. She took her position, hands pressed into the cool grass, while Bastian gripped her ankles and tried not to laugh too loudly. They tumbled, rolled, and collapsed in a heap near the oak tree, faces flushed with laughter. Grass stains bloomed across her skirt and his shirt, badges of honor for their absurd contest. When the bell rang and they dusted themselves off, neither remembered who had won. That kind of riding—wheeling, tumbling, and living—was much more their style than anything people might whisper about.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: If anyone saw her with Bastian and grass stains on her skirt, the conclusion they drew would have nothing to do with that kind of riding.

responses.text: If anyone saw her with Bastian and grass stains on her skirt, the conclusion they drew would have nothing to do with that kind of riding. The truth was, they had spent the afternoon chasing Luna moths through the overgrown field behind the abandoned greenhouse. The chase had been frantic and joyous, both of them leaping and tumbling through the grass, shrieking with laughter every time a moth slipped just out of reach. When they finally collapsed in the cool shade, breathless and victorious, her skirt was streaked green and his hands were stained with the scent of crushed clover. If anyone asked, their secret would stay safe: no whispered rumors could capture the wild, innocent magic of that summer day, nor the way she smiled at the memory long after the moths had flown away.

If anyone saw her with Bastian and grass stains on her skirt, the conclusion they drew would have nothing to do with that kind of riding. The village had long gossiped about them, but today’s adventure was nothing more than a desperate attempt to rescue a stray kitten from the tangled blackberry brambles behind the church. Bastian had climbed up first, coaxing the frightened creature with a piece of his lunch while she scrambled behind, skirt catching and knees muddied. They emerged triumphant, kitten squalling and both of them laughing, unaware of the green streaks and torn fabric. Later, when Mrs. Hargrove saw them, she raised an eyebrow, but neither cared. What mattered was the small life they’d saved, the shared secret of scratches and laughter, and the certainty that sometimes, the truth was far more innocent—and infinitely more precious—than anyone could ever imagine.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: If anyone saw her with Bastian and grass stains on her skirt, the conclusion they drew would have nothing to do with that kind of riding.

responses.text: If anyone saw her with Bastian and grass stains on her skirt, the conclusion they drew would have nothing to do with that kind of riding. No one would guess that the two of them had spent the morning searching for meteorites. It was Bastian’s wild idea after last night’s shower, convincing her that fragments could be hiding in plain sight just beyond the old soccer pitch. They crawled on hands and knees, fingers sifting through clumps of clover, giggling whenever they mistook a pebble for a piece of the cosmos. When the sun rose high, she found it—a thumb-sized stone with a charred, pitted surface. Bastian whooped and scooped her up, spinning her until they both toppled into the grass, dizzy and triumphant. The stains on her skirt were proof of their adventure. If anyone asked, she would simply smile, knowing that sometimes you have to get a little dirty to touch the stars.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Since the tanker had been empty when it had been seized, they didn’t need to dump three million barrels of crude oil into the ocean, avoiding the discovery of whether

responses.text: Since the tanker had been empty when it had been seized, they didn’t need to dump three million barrels of crude oil into the ocean, avoiding the discovery of whether the seabirds could have adapted to oil-soaked feathers or if the dolphins would have learned to leap through tar-slicked waves. Instead, the pirates found themselves staring into the cavernous holds, echoing with emptiness, and realized their information had been wrong. Captain Malek, frustrated and embarrassed before his crew, decided to stage a broadcast anyway, a ransom demand for cargo that didn’t exist. Meanwhile, the ship’s crew, locked in the galley, passed the hours inventing tales of ghost tankers and phantom cargoes to amuse each other. When the ransom went unanswered and the world’s navies ignored the pirates’ threats, Malek finally gave in. They set the tanker adrift, slunk back to their skiff, and disappeared into the horizon. The sea, spared a catastrophe, rolled on undisturbed, and only the gulls bore witness to the pirates’ ignoble retreat.

Since the tanker had been empty when it had been seized, they didn’t need to dump three million barrels of crude oil into the ocean, avoiding the discovery of whether the sea’s ancient guardians would awaken. The legends among mariners spoke of slumbering behemoths, deep beneath the waves, who detested the black poison of mankind. Had the pirates spilled the oil, perhaps the ocean would have roiled with the anger of creatures unseen for millennia. Instead, the pirates, frustrated with their empty prize, argued among themselves, unaware that below their hull, colossal eyes blinked open, having sensed the commotion. Disappointed at the lack of oil, the monsters drifted back into the abyss, but not before one whispered through the water, warning the others to watch for rusted hulls and human folly. The tanker drifted on, its secret safe, while the pirates abandoned their empty conquest, ignorant of the ancient peace they’d preserved by accident.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Since the tanker had been empty when it had been seized, they didn’t need to dump three million barrels of crude oil into the ocean, avoiding the discovery of whether

responses.text: Since the tanker had been empty when it had been seized, they didn’t need to dump three million barrels of crude oil into the ocean, avoiding the discovery of whether the water would have ignited as some of the more superstitious crew feared. Captain Rojas, standing at the bow, looked out over the moon-struck waves and wondered if this was a blessing or a curse. The plan had relied on the threat of environmental disaster to force negotiations, but with nothing in the holds, the leverage evaporated. The crew grumbled belowdecks, uncertain whether to abandon ship or continue the charade. Meanwhile, the world’s eyes watched satellites and breaking news, unaware of the empty vessel drifting in tense silence. As dawn approached, Rojas made his choice: he hoisted the white flag and radioed their surrender. The world breathed a sigh of relief, never learning just how close they’d come to testing the ocean’s tolerance for fire.

Since the tanker had been empty when it had been seized, they didn’t need to dump three million barrels of crude oil into the ocean, avoiding the discovery of whether the ocean’s currents could carry the slick to distant, unsuspecting shores. But the hijackers had expected a payload, not a hollow shell. As they searched the gleaming steel catacombs, they found only echoes and a single, cryptic note taped to the inside of the captain’s cabin: 'You can’t steal what’s already lost.' Confused and furious, the hijackers debated their next move, unaware that authorities were closing in. Outside, the night sea shimmered with innocence, but inside the tanker, tension grew with every creak of the hull. When dawn finally broke, the hijackers were forced to abandon their prize, slipping away in the predawn fog, empty-handed and haunted by a mystery they could never solve.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Since the tanker had been empty when it had been seized, they didn’t need to dump three million barrels of crude oil into the ocean, avoiding the discovery of whether

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained.

responses.text:
“That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained, her voice echoing through the near-empty conference room. Outside, the city was ablaze with protests, and the air shimmered with heat and tension. Behind her, digital screens displayed maps speckled with red dots—each one a family separated, a life uprooted. She placed a trembling hand on the folder before her, its contents classified, its secrets heavy. “But what they don’t tell you,” she continued, “is how the walls we built outside crept inside. Friendships dissolved. Teams fractured. Some of us started watching each other, reporting minor transgressions, fearing for our own security clearances.”

A young analyst, barely a year into government service, shifted in his chair. “So… Did anyone resist?”

She gave a half-smile. “Some. Quietly. Some filed papers, some leaked stories, some simply left. But most of us… we became what we feared. That’s what happens when policy isn’t just about borders, but about hearts and minds.”

“That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained. The sound of her words lingered in the sterile hall, as if the fluorescent lights themselves were listening. The old badge she wore, now faded, felt heavier than ever.

He stared at her, uncertain. “So you’re saying the changes were more than just policy?”

She nodded, fingers tracing the edge of her coffee cup. “It was a transformation. People stopped trusting each other. Every memo, every order, it spread suspicion like wildfire. Some of us started questioning our own work. The mission blurred until all we saw were shadows.”

He scribbled notes, then hesitated. “Did anyone try to stop it?”

She looked out the window, watching the flag fluttering in the breeze. “A few of us tried. But the machine was bigger than any one of us. We just tried to remember who we were before.”

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained.

responses.text:
“That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained, her gaze fixed on the rain streaking down the pane. The newcomers, the ones who had joined after the shakeups, fidgeted awkwardly around the table. “We became more fortress than agency. I remember when we prided ourselves on nuance, on balancing security with empathy. But suddenly, everything was urgency, enforcement, numbers. We were told to count detentions, not stories. To measure our worth in removals, not reunifications.”

A silence fell. Outside, the city pulsed in neon and uncertainty. One of the agents, young and sharp-eyed, asked, “Did you ever regret it?”

She sighed, the weight of years behind her. “Every day. Because it wasn’t just the immigrants who lost something. We did, too. Our mission narrowed, our hearts hardened. The lines we drew on maps started to appear between us. That’s what policy can do when the only thing it protects is fear.”

“That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained, setting down her mug and glancing at the faded photograph pinned to her cubicle wall. The photo, a group of smiling agents in happier times, seemed like a relic from another era. “We became fixers of problems we didn’t understand, implementers of rules written in panic. I once thought our job was to keep people safe, but I started to wonder who we were really protecting.”

The intern nodded, scribbling notes. “Did things ever get better?”

She shook her head. “Not really. We lost good people—people who cared, who questioned the orders. They moved on, or they stayed and hardened. The work became mechanical. It’s easy to lose yourself when the mission shifts beneath your feet.”

She paused, her voice barely a whisper. “Sometimes, I think we lost more than we’ll ever get back.”

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass.

responses.text: The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. I hesitate only a moment before giving chase, breath fogging in the cold dawn air. My flashlight beam bounces wildly, illuminating only flashes of the figure’s jacket as he darts behind the old cemetery fence. My heart pounds – not just from exertion, but from something colder threading through me: fear, or anticipation? I leap over a fallen headstone, nearly slipping myself, but my eyes are locked on his silhouette vanishing between crypts. Suddenly he stops, turning to face me, panting heavily. The silence between us is broken only by the distant caw of a crow. "Why are you following me?" his voice cracks. I step closer, lowering my light. "I think you have something that belongs to me." He laughs, bitterly. "You don’t even know what you’re asking for." I glance at his trembling hands clutching the small, glinting object. The sun crests the hill, bathing the graveyard in gold. For a moment, everything is illuminated, but the secrets between us remain shadowed.

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. I shout, but he doesn’t look back—he only accelerates, arms pumping wildly. Instinct takes over; I sprint after him, feet pounding the earth, adrenaline sharpening my focus. He veers suddenly, disappearing behind a cluster of birch trees at the edge of the park. As I round the corner, I catch a glimpse of him vaulting a low fence, nearly losing his balance. The world narrows to the slap of wet grass and the echo of my own heartbeat. Finally, in a forgotten corner near the old bandstand, he stumbles and falls hard, sprawling across the muddy ground. I slow, gasping, and approach cautiously. He rolls over, face shadowed beneath the brim of his hood. Between his fingers, a silver locket glitters. Our eyes lock—his wide with fear, mine with recognition. It’s my sister’s locket. "Why did you take it?" I demand, voice trembling. He hesitates, then whispers, "To keep her safe. They’re coming for her tonight."

Suddenly, he trips and falls, the thud echoing across the empty field. I slow, uncertain. He struggles to his knees, holding out a crumpled envelope. “Take it,” he gasps. Confusion knots my stomach, but I do as he says. The envelope is heavier than it looks. He staggers to his feet, eyes darting to the distant tree line. “Don’t open it here,” he warns, then disappears into the darkness. Left alone, I stare at the envelope, dew soaking into its corners, and wonder what I’ve just become part of.

Max winks. “You should’ve seen him, Mom. He’s quite the ladies’ man.” I know I’ll never live this down. Somewhere in his tank, Brad blows a bubble, oblivious to the scandal he’s caused. I sigh. Next time, I’m naming my pets something less provocative.

The old woman across from him, her scarf tied tightly beneath her chin, had just asked a question about the missing yam, her voice sharp as a knife. Ẹniọlá’s mind raced. If he lied, she’d know. If he told the truth, his uncle might find out. He shifted, the plastic chair creaking in protest. "Ẹniọlá, are you listening?" Her eyes narrowed. The chorus of crickets swelled, and somewhere a rooster crowed, confused by the hour. "Yes, Mama," he managed, voice barely above a whisper. The woman’s lips pursed, as if tasting his words. She leaned closer. "So, who was in the storehouse last night?" The question landed like a stone in his chest. Ẹniọlá swallowed, glancing at his feet. He wondered if courage could be scraped together as easily as yam from the earth. He took a trembling breath, deciding whether to plant the truth or bury it deeper.

Ẹniọlá scratched his thigh, worried that there might be a follow-up question. He eyed the faded blue chalkboard, the teacher’s glare sharp beneath her glasses. His answer to the first question—about colonial trade routes—had been shaky, stitched together from overheard conversations and late-night radio. The room buzzed with the restless tapping of pencils. Ẹniọlá wondered if he could conjure a distraction, maybe fake a nosebleed or drop his pencil for the fourth time. But the teacher’s gaze pinned him to his seat. "Ẹniọlá, can you tell us one more example?" she asked. His mind went blank. Outside, a lizard darted across the dusty window ledge. He tried to remember the stories his grandfather told him—something about cocoa and palm oil. "Um," he began, heart pounding, "there was also... kola nuts, ma." The teacher’s lips twitched. The class waited, the silence as thick as harmattan fog. Ẹniọlá squeezed his thigh, bracing for whatever came next, unsure if his answer would hold or crumble like old bread.

responses.text: Ẹniọlá scratched his thigh, worried that there might be a follow-up question. His heart thudded, and the silence swelled like the river after rain. Ẹniọlá scratched his thigh, worried that there might be a follow-up question. The air in the parlor was thick with the scent of old newspapers and yesterday’s stew. "There was traffic at the junction, sir," he managed, voice trembling. Grandfather’s eyes narrowed, and Ẹniọlá braced himself, certain the next question would peel back every layer of his carefully constructed story.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Ẹniọlá scratched his thigh, worried that there might be a follow-up question.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: It’ll be the l-last thing you d-do.” “Do you make such promises to all the pretty girls you meet?” Nurse Ratched asked.

responses.text:
It’ll be the l-last thing you d-do.”

“Do you make such promises to all the pretty girls you meet?” Nurse Ratched asked, lips curling into a smile that never reached her eyes. She hovered at the edge of the lamplight, her white uniform almost glowing against the dark walls of Ward C. The trembling man on the cot tried to laugh, but it came out a cough—choked, desperate.

“I’m serious,” he whispered, fingers gripping the thin blanket. “Let me out.”

Nurse Ratched’s shoes clicked softly as she drew closer. “You’re not ready,” she sang, voice soft as syrup. “You haven’t even told me your secrets yet.”

Somewhere, the night shift bell rang. She leaned over, her shadow falling like a shroud across his face. “It’s better if you don’t struggle. We have all the time in the world. And you—you have nowhere left to run.”

He closed his eyes, feeling her icy hand on his forehead. “Just let me go,” he pleaded.

Her laugh was low, almost a purr. “Not until you remember, darling. Not until you remember everything.”

It’ll be the l-last thing you d-do.”

“Do you make such promises to all the pretty girls you meet?” Nurse Ratched asked, arching a penciled brow above steely eyes. The patient, trembling, pressed himself into the corner of the sterile room, knuckles white.

He swallowed. “You don’t know what they’ll do if I talk.”

Nurse Ratched’s laugh was a soft, clinical sound. “I know more than you think. But you should worry about what happens if you don’t talk.”

He stared past her to the barred window, hoping for the silver slice of dawn. But the night stretched on, thick and silent.

“Why are you helping me?” he asked.

“I never said I was,” Nurse Ratched replied. “But I do so like to watch the brave ones squirm. Now, shall we begin?”

She drew the curtain, shutting out the world. The only thing left was the echo of his own heartbeat, and the glint of her syringe under the harsh fluorescent light.

“Do you make such promises to all the pretty girls you meet?” Nurse Ratched asked, her voice as smooth as the starch in her uniform. She smiled, placing a gloved hand on his wrist, pinning him gently but firmly. “That’s good. Fear clouds the mind. And I want you to remember everything we talk about tonight.”

He tried to pull away, but the restraints held. “Please, I—”

It’ll be the l-last thing you d-do.”

“Do you make such promises to all the pretty girls you meet?” Nurse Ratched asked, her tone laced with mockery. She snapped her latex gloves, the sound echoing off the tiled walls. He whimpered, glancing at the locked door. “You don’t have to do this.”

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: It’ll be the l-last thing you d-do.” “Do you make such promises to all the pretty girls you meet?” Nurse Ratched asked.

responses.text:
It’ll be the l-last thing you d-do.”

“Do you make such promises to all the pretty girls you meet?” Nurse Ratched asked, her eyes never leaving the playing card she was folding into a sharp little boat. The patient, confined to his wheelchair by more than straps, watched the paper vessel with a mixture of longing and dread. Around them, the ward hummed with the restless movements of other souls, each lost in their own labyrinth.

He tried again, voice steadier. “I mean it. I have nothing left to lose.”

She placed the boat on the windowsill, its prow pointed toward the storm-lashed garden. “That’s where you’re wrong, darling. Here, we always have something left to lose.”

Lightning flared, illuminating the boat’s shadow against the glass. Nurse Ratched leaned in, her voice velvet-soft. “But if you truly want out, perhaps you’ll show me how far you’re willing to go.”

The boat trembled as thunder rolled. He realized, with a sinking heart, that the real storm was inside, and she was its architect.

Together, they uncovered the labyrinthine corruption at the heart of the city, their partnership forged in shadows and ink. When the century finally turned, it was her name on the headlines—but in the margins, scribbled in her unmistakable hand, was always a message for him: "Thank you for believing in the impossible."

to write exposés on the criminal justice system from a perspective nobody else dared to attempt. prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Somewhere around the turn of the century he met an enterprising young reporter named Cecilia Marks, who was making a name for herself by getting thrown into prisons in order

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground.

responses.text: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. His vision flickered, then faded into a blackness that seethed with memory and regret. Far above, the roar of the crowd was muffled, as if underwater. He tried to move, but his limbs felt distant, detached. In the darkness, a single image glimmered: his little sister’s face, the way she’d smiled at him that morning, unaware of the debts he carried or the promises he’d made to dangerous men. When he finally blinked his eyes open, the world reeled. A blurry figure crouched beside him, whispering in a language he almost recognized. Hands searched his pockets, and something cold pressed against his cheek. He tried to speak, but his mouth filled with metallic tang. Was this how it ended? With a punch, a secret, and the echo of a promise he could never keep? He closed his eyes again, feeling the city’s pulse beneath the concrete, hoping—just for a moment—that someone, somewhere, would remember him kindly.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. Above the ringing in his ears, he registered laughter—sharp, cruel, echoing off the alley’s brick walls. Rain tapped rhythmically on the pavement, pooling around his cheek as he fought to stay conscious. He smelled copper and garbage, felt the grit of gravel biting into his skin. Blurry shadows loomed, arguing in hushed, frantic voices. ‘He’s got it, check his pockets!’ someone hissed. Hands rifled through his jacket, yanking free the crumpled envelope he’d been told never to lose. He tried to protest, but the world spun. A boot nudged his ribs. ‘Should we finish it?’ ‘No, leave him. He’s nothing.’ Footsteps faded. He lay shivering, wondering if he’d wake to daylight or if this night would swallow him whole. Somewhere, a siren wailed, far away and indifferent. His last clear thought was of the secret he’d failed to keep—and the price that would be paid for his weakness.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground.

responses.text: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. The world spun in slow motion, colors bleeding into each other. He could barely register the taste of blood in his mouth or the gravel digging into his cheek. A distant voice whispered, "Shouldn't have come here alone." He tried to focus, to remember why he'd walked into the abandoned warehouse. Above him, the flicker of a broken neon sign cast wavering shadows across the faces of his assailants. One of them knelt beside him, slipping something cold into his palm before melting back into the gloom. "You’re not the only one with secrets," she murmured. As his consciousness ebbed, his fingers closed around a small, metallic object—an old locket, engraved with the initials of someone he thought he'd lost forever. Even as darkness claimed him, a single truth burned brighter than the pain: this was only the beginning.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. The alley spun, neon lights warping in his periphery. He listened, dazed, to the hurried footsteps and the distant screech of tires. For a moment, he thought of his mother’s voice, gentle and worried, telling him not to get involved. But he had, and now here he was—face pressed to cold pavement, the envelope still tucked inside his coat. Someone knelt beside him, breath hot and desperate. "Did you get it?" the voice whispered. He tried to nod, but his body refused. Darkness crept in, swallowing the city’s glow. As he faded, he clung to the hope that the evidence he’d risked everything to steal would make it out, even if he did not. Somewhere above, rain began to fall, washing away the blood and secrets alike.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground.

responses.text: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. But before the darkness could claim him, the world stuttered and rewound. The fist retracted, the pain evaporated, and he found himself standing upright in the same dingy bar, a half-empty glass in his hand. The jukebox played the same scratchy tune, and the air reeked of stale beer. Confused, he glanced at the clock—1:12 AM, again. He blinked, and the fight replayed: the same insult, the same swing, the same agony. Over and over, he relived the moment, unable to change the outcome no matter how he ducked, pleaded, or fought back. Each time, the world reset, trapping him in a loop of violence and regret. Somewhere between loops, he realized this wasn’t punishment—it was a challenge. The answer didn’t lie in avoiding the blow, but in understanding why it always landed. As he faced his attacker for the hundredth time, he finally saw the pain in the other man’s eyes—a reflection of his own. For the first time, he reached out, not to fight, but to forgive.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained.

responses.text:
“That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained, her voice quiet but steely as she looked out over the deserted hallway. The fluorescent lights flickered above, casting long shadows on the linoleum floor. “It hollowed us out from the inside. Good people left, protocols got twisted. I remember the day we were told to separate families. There wasn’t a dry eye in the room, but we did it. Some of us protested, some resigned. I stayed, thinking I could make a difference.”

Tyrell leaned against the wall, arms folded. “Did you?”

She shook her head. “Not the way I hoped. Every day, I watched procedures get harsher, watched my colleagues lose faith. The department changed. We changed. Now, every time I walk these halls, I feel the ghosts of what we used to be.”

Tyrell exhaled slowly, the gravity of her words settling over them. Outside, a storm rumbled. “So why stay?”

She shrugged, a sad smile flickering. “Because someone had to remember what we were. And maybe, someday, help us be better again.”

"That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration," she explained, her hands clasped in her lap. "It turned the mission upside down. Instead of protecting the nation from threats, we started seeing threats everywhere: in families, in children, in people just trying to get by."

She glanced at the old badge on her desk, its edges worn. "I joined DHS to help people, to keep the country safe. But I watched as the rules changed—how we built walls both literal and figurative. How agents, once proud of their service, began questioning what they were being asked to do."

Her voice trembled. "I remember the day the new policy memo arrived. We stopped focusing on traffickers and started targeting day laborers, mothers, anyone without papers. I saw colleagues break down. Some quit. Others doubled down."

She paused, looking me in the eye. "We forgot what we stood for. And now, even after the administration changed, I wonder if we’ll ever really find our way back."

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained.

responses.text:
“That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained, fingers drumming nervously on the conference table. “It was like watching a river change course overnight, flooding old boundaries and eroding the foundations we’d built for years. Suddenly, the mission shifted. Instead of collaboration, there was suspicion. Walls went up—literal and bureaucratic. I remember one morning, the new directives came in. We had to start auditing our own agents, checking for ideological purity. Loyalty tests, they called them.”

Her colleague, Miguel, stared at the ceiling. “I lost three friends that month. Good agents. People who believed in the law, but not in cruelty.”

She nodded, sadness flickering in her eyes. “It wasn’t just about policy. It was about fear. About making us afraid of each other. That’s what changed the Department—not just the paperwork or the press conferences. It was the trust. Once that’s gone, what’s left?”

Miguel sighed. “Just uniforms and locked doors.”

"That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration," she explained, her gaze lost in the distance as rain streaked down the window. "It became more about exclusion than protection. Every week, a new directive landed on my desk—more detentions, more surveillance, less compassion. The culture shifted, you could feel it in the elevator, in the way people stopped talking about their families at work."

She paused, twisting the silver ring on her finger. "I remember Jorge, who used to organize potlucks for everyone. One day he just stopped coming in. Rumors said he spoke out at a meeting. After that, people kept their heads down, did what they were told. The mission was lost in the noise."

A long silence settled between us. "Now, I wonder if the department can ever be what it was meant to be. Or if we’re too far gone to remember what that even was."

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained.

responses.text:
“That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained, her tone laced with irony as she led me through a labyrinth of archives. “We became archivists of our own contradictions. The files you see here—stacks of affidavits, memos, hastily scrawled notes—are monuments to a bureaucracy at war with itself.”

She stopped in front of a locked cabinet. “Inside are the directives that never made it to daylight. One suggested microchipping asylum seekers. Another proposed using AI to predict ‘undesirable’ border crossings. Some called it innovation. I called it paranoia.”

She brushed dust from a yellowed folder. “I watched colleagues morph into gatekeepers of suspicion. Decision-making grew arbitrary—one day compassion, the next day cruelty. The mission statement on the wall stayed the same, but the meaning warped.”

She handed me a worn photograph: agents in a break room, laughing. “I keep this as proof that we were human once. When the tide turned, some of us held on to that memory. Most days, it feels like a relic.”

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: The patient coming in is a thirty-two-year-old female found unresponsive while diving near Alki Beach.” “Diving?” Evelyn nods.

responses.text:
“Yes, diving,” Evelyn said, her voice tight. “Apparently free diving. She was found by another diver, no equipment failure, just… didn’t resurface.”

Dr. Malik’s mind raced through possible differentials as they wheeled the woman into Trauma 2. Salt water glistened on her wetsuit. Her lips were blue, hair tangled with seaweed. “Vitals?” he asked, glancing at the monitor. 

“Heart rate 42, sats 78% on non-rebreather. Pupils sluggish.” Evelyn peeled off the diver’s glove, revealing a silver ring and a tattoo of a tiny octopus.

“Let’s start with airway and get a blood gas,” Dr. Malik said, but his curiosity was piqued. He’d heard of the so-called ‘diver’s reflex’—how submersion sparked strange things in the human body. As the team worked, he noticed a faint shimmer on the patient’s neck, an indentation just below her ear. Was it a wound, or something else?

The monitor beeped. The woman’s eyes fluttered open, briefly. She gasped a word that sounded like “Below.”

Evelyn leaned in. “What’s below?”

The woman’s pulse quickened. “Don’t go back,” she whispered, before her eyes closed again, leaving the medical team with more questions than answers.

Evelyn nods, her knuckles white on the gurney rail. “Yes. She was diving solo, according to the friend who called it in. No sign of trauma, but she’s got a strange rash on her arms.”

Dr. Patel glances down, frowning at the patient’s skin. Flecks of red weave into a lattice pattern, almost like coral. “Get a tox screen,” he orders, but Evelyn’s already ahead, drawing blood and setting up the monitor.

As they work, the woman’s eyelids flutter. Her lips part and she murmurs, “Below the wreck.”

Evelyn leans closer. “What did you say?”

The woman’s eyes flicker under closed lids. “They’re waiting. Don’t let them in.”

A shiver dances up Evelyn’s spine. She glances at Dr. Patel, who shrugs, but she notices him touching his own arm, tracing an imaginary pattern.
