Now, in the dim hospital room, she saw him clearly—smiling, holding her mother’s hand, as if the last decade had been a fevered dream. He spoke softly, recounting stories from her childhood that Mara remembered only in fragments, voices echoing across time. The monitors beeped steadily, grounding her in the present. She reached out, half-expecting her hand to pass through him, but his grip was warm, real. Tears blurred her vision. "You came back," she whispered, hope and fear tangled in her throat. He nodded, eyes shining. "I never left," he said. The world outside the window glimmered with the first light of dawn, and Mara knew, whatever the truth, she would carry this moment—this impossible reunion—forever, nestled close to her heart, a secret light against the dark.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: His father was alive beside her.

responses.text: His father was alive beside her. In the pale glow of the morning, Clara rubbed her eyes, certain she was still lost in a half-remembered dream. Yet there he was, sitting at the edge of her mother’s bed, hands folded, the familiar scar above his eyebrow catching the light. Years had passed since the funeral, since she’d placed flowers on his grave and whispered all the words she never got to say. Now, her mother beamed, untouched by time or sorrow, and Clara’s heart pounded with hope and dread. "You found your way back," she breathed, watching the lines of his face shift, uncertain if she dared to believe. He smiled, a gentle sadness lingering. "Just for a moment," he replied, voice echoing with memory. Clara reached out, desperate to hold him, but her fingers closed around empty air. The sun crested the horizon; the vision faded, leaving only warmth and a whisper of forgiveness in the space where he had been.

His father was alive beside her. The world had not ended, though it felt as if it should have. Marisol blinked, unable to reconcile the man’s familiar features with the years of emptiness his absence had left. He reached for her mother’s hand, a gesture so ordinary it threatened to unravel her. For weeks, strange things had happened in the house: clocks ticking backward, shadows moving against the grain of the light. Now, with the impossible before her, Marisol understood. The boundaries between past and present had unraveled, and in this fragile dawn, her family sat together once more. She wanted to ask questions—how, why, what now—but the words stuck. Instead, she watched her parents’ smiles meet, a silent promise bridging decades of loss. When the sun rose, he would be gone. But for now, Marisol let herself believe in miracles, just once more.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: His father was alive beside her.

responses.text: His father was alive beside her. In the cavernous echo of the subway station, the old man’s laughter bounced off the tiled walls, mixing with the distant screech of rails. Miri stood frozen, suitcase dangling from her hand, as her father leaned in close to her mother, sharing a secret she could not hear. It was impossible—she had watched him slip away years ago, a fading star in a hospital bed. But here, on the platform between worlds, he wore his favorite hat, the one she’d hidden away in a box of memories. Miri’s feet moved of their own accord, carrying her toward the pair. As she drew near, her father turned, his eyes bright with mischief and something ancient. “Trains come and go, but some reunions run deeper than time,” he whispered. Miri blinked, and suddenly the station was empty, only the echo of laughter and the scent of pipe tobacco lingering in the air. She smiled, stepping into her journey, heart lighter than it had been in years.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back.

responses.text: These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. She lined them up on her windowsill, from the one-eared rabbit to the velvet-worn bear, whispering secrets into their stitched ears every night. When she grew older, she started sewing new ones, patching felt into improbable creatures: a whale with dragonfly wings, a fox with a crown. Each one was a silent companion, absorbing her laughter and tears. One evening, as she buttoned eyes onto a tiny wolf, she heard a faint giggle from behind her. The animals were clustered together, heads tilted, eyes glinting in the lamplight. She wasn’t sure if she’d imagined it, but the comfort remained, undiminished. Even when she moved away, she carried the smallest bear with her—a reminder that some kinds of love don’t need to be returned to last forever.

These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. When she was five, her favorite was a moth-eaten dog named Pickles. She would talk to Pickles about the monsters under her bed and her dreams of becoming a paleontologist. One night, lightning struck the old willow in their yard, and she clutched Pickles to her chest, feeling his faded fur grow damp with her tears. Years later, after her parents’ divorce, she found Pickles in a box. The dog’s stitched smile hadn’t changed, even though everything else had. She realized that maybe loving something, even something silent and worn, was a way to anchor herself when the world spun too fast. As she tucked Pickles onto her dorm bed, she whispered, “Thank you,” and felt, for a moment, that maybe he understood.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back.

responses.text: These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. When her mother left, the animals became her confidants, each one assigned to a particular memory: the blue rabbit for bedtime songs, the lion for rainy afternoons. She’d arrange them in a circle each night, tucking them in with the same care she wished someone would show her. Years passed, and her collection grew, until her bed was an island in a sea of plush. One evening, after a particularly hard day, she pressed her face into the bear’s matted fur and sobbed. In the silence that followed, she listened, hoping for a response. There was none—just the quiet presence of her silent friends. Yet, in that stillness, she felt held. She understood then that love didn’t always need to be reciprocated to be real.

These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. She named each one with purpose: Sir Hopsalot, Lady Twinkle, Captain Buttons. Every night, she performed elaborate bedtime ceremonies, tucking them under patchwork blankets and reciting stories only they could hear. One winter, a blizzard knocked out the power, and she gathered the animals close, telling them it would be all right. Their button eyes offered no reassurance, but their silent companionship steadied her. Years later, as she boxed them up to move away, she traced their faded seams, realizing that loving them had taught her to give comfort freely, even when nothing was given in return. In their stillness, she had discovered her own capacity for kindness.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back.

responses.text: These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. They sat in a mismatched parliament on her bookshelf, silent witnesses to her childhood rituals. But on the night of her tenth birthday, a strange hush fell over her room, and the moonlight etched silver outlines around their fuzzy shapes. She reached for her oldest friend, a penguin missing one flipper, and whispered a wish. To her astonishment, the penguin blinked—once, slowly—then settled back into stillness. The next morning, doubt clouded her memory, but the faint warmth in the penguin’s plush belly lingered. Years later, after heartbreak and loss, she found herself clutching that same penguin, its threadbare body unchanged but somehow more familiar than ever. She realized then that love, even when unreturned, could spark magic in the most unlikely places, and that perhaps her stuffed friends had been loving her back all along—in ways she’d only just begun to understand.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Without a goodbye.

responses.text:
Without a goodbye, the morning sun cracked over the horizon, spilling gold onto the empty porch where Cassie waited. The suitcase at her feet was half-zipped, her jacket slung over the rail. She’d spent the night listening for footsteps, for the creak of the gate, for his voice humming from the garden. But the only sound was the wind, tugging at the note he’d left—if you could call it a note. Just three words, scrawled on the back of an old receipt: "You’ll be fine."

Cassie pressed her palm to the wood, feeling the ridges where his hands had tightened, day after day, summer after summer. She had memorized the world in which they lived, the rhythm of their laughter and the silences that grew between them. Now, silence stretched on, endless.

She tucked the note into her pocket, lifted her suitcase, and stepped from the porch. In the garden, the tomatoes had ripened overnight, bursting with color. Cassie plucked one, bit into its sweetness, and let the juice run down her chin. She walked away, not looking back, tasting the memory of what had been, growing braver with every step.

Without a goodbye, the city swallowed him whole. One moment, Jae was standing at the corner of 7th and Pine, backpack slung over one shoulder, eyes tracing the faded mural across the street. The next, he had faded into the crowd—a ripple in the gray tide of commuters and dreamers. No farewell, no backward glance. Just the shuffle of shoes and the click of a traffic signal.

For weeks, Leena replayed their last conversation, searching for missed clues in the lull between words. She found meaning in the cracks, in the way he’d fiddled with his keys, or the way his laughter had sounded like a question. She haunted the corner in the mornings, half-hoping, half-dreading he’d reappear. But the city never paused. It pulsed and churned, indifferent.

In time, Leena learned to read the city’s other stories: the whispered secrets in coffee shop corners, the hope in the eyes of strangers. She found herself reflected in the faces brushing past, each one holding a thousand untold goodbyes. And though Jae’s memory lingered, she learned to move forward, her own story unfolding, unfinished.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Without a goodbye.

responses.text:
Without a goodbye, the rain fell with a stubborn persistence, drumming against the old glass as if to drown out the memory of her absence. The teacup she’d left on the kitchen table still held a ring of chamomile, the faintest trace of her lipstick marking the rim. Sam wandered the house, each room echoing with the ghost of her laughter—so recent, so impossible to reclaim. He opened the wardrobe, half-expecting a note, a clue, some small sign that her departure was a mistake. But there was nothing but the faint scent of lavender and the soft rustle of empty dresses.

Outside, the garden wilted beneath the gray sky. Sam knelt by the row of marigolds she’d planted in the spring, tracing the soil with trembling fingers. He whispered apologies to the silence, words meant for ears that would never hear them. When the rain eased and sunlight pierced the clouds, Sam rose, mud on his knees, and turned toward the open road. With every step, he carried the weight of her absence—a farewell unspoken, forever lingering.

Without a goodbye, the carousel spun in the abandoned amusement park, lights flickering in the fog. Leo stood at the edge of the platform, clutching a faded photograph of his brother. They’d promised to ride together every summer, but this year, the second horse from the left remained empty. Leo circled the carousel, searching for a sign, a message, anything that would explain the sudden vanishing act. He remembered laughter echoing across the midway, the thrill of midnight races, the shared secrets. Now, even the shadows seemed to hold their breath.

He slipped the photograph into his pocket and climbed onto the empty horse. As the carousel groaned to life, memories blurred with the spinning lights—his brother’s voice calling out, the warmth of strong arms around his shoulders. Leo closed his eyes, letting the music carry him through the dusk. He whispered a farewell the wind might carry, spinning onward, chasing the echo of a goodbye never spoken.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Without a goodbye.

responses.text: Without a goodbye, the old trolley rattled away, leaving only the scent of metal and rain in its wake. Myra stood on the cracked cobblestone platform, clutching the yellow umbrella she’d borrowed but never meant to return. The city, a labyrinth of narrow alleys and flickering lamps, seemed to hold its breath. She wandered through the marketplace, past the spice stalls and paper lanterns, remembering the stories he used to tell—of secret gardens and invisible doors. She found herself at the river’s edge, where the water curled in silent eddies, carrying away the wishes of those brave enough to let go. Myra knelt and let the umbrella drift into the current, watching it spin and bob, shrinking into the mist. She realized there are departures that do not require words, only the quiet courage to step forward. The city exhaled, and Myra turned toward the waking dawn, the memory of a farewell dissolving in the hush between heartbeats.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back.

responses.text:
These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. She arranged them in a crescent moon on her bed every night, tucking them beneath the covers, whispering secrets into their polyester ears. Sometimes she waited for them to respond, listening for the soft crinkle of fabric or the imagined sigh of a plush bear. Their silence taught her patience, their stillness a lesson in devotion unreturned. 

When she was seven, she lost her favorite—an owl with one glass eye—to the rain, after leaving it on the porch during a thunderstorm. She cried for hours, hugging the damp, sodden creature, hoping her warmth could bring it back. But the owl remained mute, its feathers forever matted. Years later, she kept every animal—worn, patched, faded—in a trunk at the foot of her bed. She never stopped loving them, even as she learned to love people who sometimes left her lonely. Their silent presence reminded her that love, real love, wasn’t always about being loved back. Sometimes, it was about giving and letting go, about the soft weight of a bear in your arms and the ache when you realize it’s just stuffing and thread.

These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. She’d lined them up on her windowsill, a mismatched parliament of squishy creatures with stitched smiles and button eyes. Each night, she chose one to cradle as she drifted off—a small, silent ritual against the dark. When she cried, their fur soaked up her tears; when she laughed, she arranged them to watch, certain they understood. 

But over time, she began to notice the gaps in their gaze, the way their heads slumped, the way the seams wore thin. She whispered apologies for the times she forgot them under the bed or left them in the cold. When other children teased her for bringing a tattered bunny to school, she clutched it tighter, feeling its battered softness against her palm. Even now, years later, with the animals packed away in boxes, she kept one—her first bear—on her bookshelf. Sometimes she caught herself speaking to it, voice soft and careful, as though love could make cotton real. Loving them had taught her tenderness, and how to hold on, even when holding on hurt.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back.

responses.text:
These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. She gave them names from storybooks and embroidered tiny hearts on their bellies, convinced that would bring them to life. Her favorite—a lopsided giraffe with a crooked neck—sat in the place of honor, always at her side. She read to him by flashlight long after bedtime, whispered her hopes into his fabric ears, and shared her worries with his stitched-on smile. When he was accidentally left behind at the park, she spent days searching, her heart heavy with the ache of absence. 

Years later, she found the giraffe in a lost-and-found bin, faded and frayed. She pressed him to her chest, realizing that loving something didn’t mean it would stay, or love her in return. But it also didn’t mean she should stop. The lesson lingered, weaving through the years and relationships that followed: love is a gift you give, not a guarantee you get back. And sometimes, the giving was enough.

These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. The tiny lion with its threadbare mane, the floppy rabbit with its unraveling ear, the faded dragon that guarded her pillow—each was cherished, though none ever returned her affection. She built kingdoms for them out of shoeboxes and blankets, made them the guests of honor at invisible tea parties. In the quiet hours after lights-out, she confessed her secrets to their button eyes, waiting for comfort that never came. 

One day, she tried leaving a note for them: "Do you love me too?" In the morning, the note was untouched, but she folded it carefully into the lion’s paw. Over the years, as she outgrew tea sets and shoebox castles, she learned that loving could mean giving without expecting anything back. Still, when she stumbled across the lion years later, she found the note, yellowed but intact, and smiled at the memory of love bravely given, even when it seemed to echo into silence.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back.

responses.text: These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. She made a habit of inventing elaborate stories for each one: the velvet mouse was a retired magician, the faded elephant a secret poet, the fox a time traveler who’d misplaced his watch. She stitched tiny clothes and paper crowns, arranging coronations and rescue missions on her bedroom floor. When her father left, she held the mouse tight, whispering to him everything she wished she could say aloud. In the stillness, the animals’ silence became a comfort, a space where her imagination could fill in the gaps. As she grew older, the stories grew stranger—sometimes the fox would vanish for days, sometimes the mouse would forget her name. The animals never complained, never demanded, never left. They taught her that love could survive on hope and memory, that it could be both quiet and wild. By the time she packed them away for college, she realized she’d learned to love the world’s silences, and to find magic in things that could never quite love her back.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Oh, I’m great.

responses.text: Oh, I’m great. At least, that’s what I tell everyone. I smile, wave, and laugh at all the right moments, but what they don’t know is that every morning, I wake up in a world that has forgotten color. The rain outside my window is always gray, and the birds sing in monotone. I go about my day on autopilot, checking off tasks as if they’re lines in a script. At work, I’m the first to volunteer for overtime, the last to leave the breakroom, always making sure no one suspects anything is amiss. But tonight, after the city lights have dimmed and the world is quiet, I finally let myself breathe. I take out the old box from under my bed—the one filled with letters I wrote to myself as a child. Each note is a splash of color, a memory of laughter, a reminder of hope. As I read them, the grayness starts to recede, just a little. Maybe tomorrow, when someone asks how I am, I’ll say, “I’m working on it,” and that will be enough.

Oh, I’m great. That’s what I said, even as my spaceship spun out of control, lights flashing warnings in every language I could barely recognize. The AI assistant, Beep, sounded calm, but I knew from the way its voice wavered that we were in trouble. I gripped the console, sweat beading on my forehead, and tried to remember my training. Outside, the stars blurred into wild streaks, and the planet below loomed larger with every passing second. "Emergency landing protocol engaged," Beep droned, and suddenly, gravity pressed me into my seat. I closed my eyes and thought of home, of the fields of lavender and the way my brother used to tease me about being the family’s worst pilot. The ship shuddered as we entered the atmosphere, and I braced myself for impact. When we finally touched down—rough, but alive—I opened my eyes and laughed, breathless. “I’m great,” I whispered, this time almost believing it.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Oh, I’m great.

responses.text: Oh, I’m great. Or at least, that’s the answer I’ve practiced for weeks. Tonight’s gala is crawling with the city’s finest—politicians, artists, and the odd criminal disguised as a philanthropist. My sequined dress glimmers under chandeliers, a perfect mask for the turmoil within. I float from conversation to conversation, clutching my champagne flute, recounting stories that aren’t quite true. No one notices the trembling in my hands or the way my eyes dart to the exit every few minutes. I laugh at jokes, nod at plans, and mirror the confidence I wish I felt. But as midnight approaches, a masked stranger slips me a card, the ink still wet: “We know.” My heart stutters. Suddenly, my practiced lines dissolve. I excuse myself, fleeing down marble corridors, the echo of my heels a countdown. Outside, the air is raw and honest. I can finally breathe. For the first time all night, I don’t have to pretend.

Oh, I’m great. That’s what I blurt out when the doctor asks, even though my hands won’t stop fidgeting with the hem of my shirt. The office smells faintly of antiseptic and peppermint, and I can hear the soft tapping of rain against the window. She looks up from her clipboard, eyebrow raised, as if she already knows the truth. I try to steady my breath, counting each inhale, but the words I want to say tangle in my throat. I remember my grandmother’s advice: "If you say it enough, it becomes real." So I smile wider, as if that will convince both of us. The doctor waits, patient and silent, until the room feels too big and small all at once. Finally, I let out a shaky laugh. "Actually, maybe I’m not so great." And in that moment, my honesty feels like the bravest thing I’ve ever done.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Oh, I’m great.

responses.text: Oh, I’m great. I’m so great, in fact, that I can talk to pigeons—specifically one pigeon, named Reginald, who insists he’s an undercover detective. Every morning, Reginald perches on my windowsill, top hat slightly askew, and tells me tales of the city’s most notorious bread thieves. Today, he reported a crime so shocking that even the local sparrows are gossiping: someone swapped all the breadcrumbs in the park for tiny rubber ducks. Reginald suspects the squirrels, but I’m not so sure. There’s something shifty about that one-legged seagull by the fountain. Armed with a pocketful of sunflower seeds and a magnifying glass, I set off to crack the case. As I interrogate the ducks, passersby give me odd looks, but I don’t mind. After all, when you’re great—and have a pigeon detective partner—anything is possible.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced.

responses.text:
He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced. But by then, the wheels of justice had already begun to turn. Detective Larkin, who’d taken the confession, stared at the statement with a sense of creeping dread. He knew the case was shaky, but pressure from above had made him push harder than he should have. Now, the accused, a gaunt man named Tomas, was taking back every word, and his lawyer was shouting about civil rights and illegal tactics.

Meanwhile, outside the station, a group of protesters had begun to gather. Tomas’ wife, Elena, clutched their son’s hand, her face set with determination. She knew her husband was innocent, and she wouldn’t rest until everyone else knew it too. As the case unraveled, new evidence surfaced—a blurry video from a nearby shop that showed someone else near the scene of the crime. Detective Larkin realized he’d been wrong. As he watched the video, his heart pounded. He’d have to face the consequences, but maybe, just maybe, he could help set things right before it was too late.

He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced. The press, already feasting on the drama, barely paused to report the reversal. Headlines blared ‘Killer Confesses!’ while the truth slipped quietly out the back door. In his cramped apartment, Julian stared at the wall, hands trembling. He remembered the harsh lights, the endless questions, the promises of mercy if he just said the words. He remembered the sharp taste of fear, how it had twisted his tongue into betrayal.

His public defender, a tired man with a cluttered briefcase, tried to reassure him, but Julian saw the doubt in his eyes. Outside, rain tapped the window. Somewhere in the city, the real culprit was free, moving through shadows, unburdened. Julian wondered if the justice system could ever untangle the knot it had tied around his life. Maybe someone would believe him this time. Maybe not. He closed his eyes, listening to the rain, and hoped that the storm would wash away more than just the city’s grime.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced.

responses.text:
He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced. The room where he signed the statement still smelled of stale coffee and bleach, but now it felt colder. His lawyer pressed him for details, and he described the relentless questions, the promises whispered between threats. He remembered the officers’ faces—impassive, but their eyes too sharp, too eager. As word of his recantation spread, the city’s rumor mill churned. Some called him a liar, others a victim. In the courthouse, his mother’s hands shook as she clutched her rosary beads. The prosecutor hesitated, sensing the case unraveling. 

Meanwhile, a new detective reviewed the evidence, noticing things that hadn’t fit before—missing time stamps, a witness dismissed too quickly. The truth, it seemed, had always been hidden in plain sight. As the trial date approached, the tide of public opinion began to shift. He waited, uncertain if the world would believe him this time, or if his voice would be drowned out once again.

He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced. The news left the police department scrambling, and the case’s lead detective, Marquez, replayed the interview tapes. Marquez noticed the subtle tremor in the suspect’s voice, the way he glanced nervously at the one-way mirror. Maybe the suspect wasn’t lying after all. Maybe someone had pushed him too hard, looking for a quick win. 

Outside, the city buzzed with rumors. Bloggers speculated about misconduct; activists planned rallies. In his cell, the accused drew patterns on the wall with a blunt pencil, each line a silent protest. His mother visited, her eyes red-rimmed but hopeful. Marquez, torn between loyalty and conscience, began to dig deeper. He found a misplaced witness statement, overlooked in the rush. It hinted at another suspect entirely. For the first time, Marquez questioned not just the confession, but the very foundation of the case.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced.

responses.text:
He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced. The midnight air in the interrogation room had tasted metallic, thick with expectation. Now, in the sanctuary of his grandmother’s kitchen, he watched her stir tea leaves, her gnarled fingers trembling. “They made you say it, didn’t they?” she whispered. He nodded, tears stinging his eyes. 

The town’s rumor mill spun faster than ever—some said he was guilty, others claimed the police would do anything for a quick conviction. Outside, the autumn wind rattled the windowpanes as he resolved to find the strength to fight back. With his grandmother’s quiet encouragement, he began to write his own account, word by word, late into the night. When the hearing came, his voice didn’t tremble. He described the pressure, the threats, the promises that vanished with daylight. He didn’t know if it would be enough, but for the first time, he felt the truth might finally have a chance to breathe.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I know that’s right.” “Your turn, August,” Julian prompted.

responses.text:
I know that’s right.” “Your turn, August,” Julian prompted.

August hesitated, his fingers nervously tapping the battered tabletop. The flickering candlelight cast their shadows large and uncertain against the peeling wallpaper. He glanced at the old deck of cards between them, each card’s edge softened by years of restless hands. This wasn’t just a game tonight; the stakes were invisible yet impossibly high.

He drew a card, but before revealing it, he looked Julian in the eye. “If I win, you’ll tell me the truth. About the attic.”

Julian’s lips tightened, but he nodded. “And if I win?”

August considered. The wind rattled the windowpane. “Then I’ll go up there myself. Tonight.”

They both knew what that meant. The attic door had been locked since last spring, when the noises started. But secrets had their own way of slipping through cracks.

August flipped the card. The Queen of Spades stared up at them, her face coldly triumphant. Julian’s gaze darkened.

“All right,” he said. “You win. But you might wish you hadn’t.”

I know that’s right.” “Your turn, August,” Julian prompted.

August took a slow breath and peered down at the battered Ouija board that separated them. The planchette trembled under his fingers as he tried to steady his nerves. Shadows flickered in the corners of the abandoned rec room, and the whisper of rain against the broken windows made every hair on his arms stand on end.

He moved the planchette. “Is there… anyone here with us?”

For a moment, nothing. Then the planchette jerked beneath his touch, spelling out: Y-E-S.

Julian stifled a nervous laugh, but August’s heart pounded. “Who are you?” he asked, voice barely above a whisper.

The planchette slid again: S-T-A-Y.

Julian’s bravado faltered. “Did we just invite something?”

August tried to pull his hand away, but it wouldn’t move. A cold pressure wrapped around his wrist. The candle sputtered.

Outside, thunder cracked. Inside, the planchette spelled one final word: R-U-N.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I know that’s right.” “Your turn, August,” Julian prompted.

responses.text:
I know that’s right.” “Your turn, August,” Julian prompted.

August stared into the dim light, feeling the hush of the old library press down on him. His friends watched expectantly, their faces illuminated by the pale glow of phones left forgotten on the table. August cleared his throat, then reached for the battered, leather-bound book in the center.

He recited the passage, his voice quivering: “In the heart of the labyrinth, you must choose: truth, or dare.”

A sudden gust rattled the stained-glass window. Each friend tensed, recalling the legend: completing the game would reveal a secret hidden for centuries. But if a player refused a challenge, the labyrinth’s curse would claim them.

Julian gave a nervous smile. “So, August, truth or dare?”

August swallowed. “Dare.”

Julian’s eyes sparkled with mischief and fear. “Go to the forbidden shelves and bring back the red book.”

August rose, pulse pounding, and stepped into the aisle. The air grew colder. In the deepest corner, a crimson book gleamed beneath the dust. As he touched it, the room behind him faded into silence, and a whisper curled through the darkness: “Welcome, August.”

I know that’s right.” “Your turn, August,” Julian prompted.

August slid his pawn forward, but the old chessboard groaned in protest, its edges curling from the dampness that always clung to the basement. “Check,” he said quietly.

Julian’s eyes narrowed. “You’re getting better.”

But August’s focus drifted as he heard the familiar scraping behind the walls. He tried to ignore it, tried to stay in the game, but the sound grew louder. Julian seemed not to notice, or maybe he’d grown used to it.

Suddenly, a cold draft brushed past August’s ankle. He shivered and glanced at Julian, searching for reassurance.

Julian met his gaze, his voice a whisper this time. “It’s okay, August. If you win, you get to ask it one question.”

August’s breath caught. The rules were simple, but the answers never were—and the thing in the walls always told the truth. He moved his queen, hesitating just before toppling Julian’s king. Somewhere in the shadows, something smiled.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I know that’s right.” “Your turn, August,” Julian prompted.

responses.text:
I know that’s right.” “Your turn, August,” Julian prompted.

August hesitated, looking down at the circle chalked onto the cracked concrete. Five candles flickered, their flames trembling in the midnight air. Outside, the city was just a distant hum, but in the abandoned warehouse, every breath seemed to echo.

He reached into the velvet bag and pulled out a handful of polished stones. The others watched him, faces half-hidden by shadow, eyes reflecting the candlelight. August’s hand shook as he let the stones fall, scattering across the center of the circle.

Each stone landed with a sharp click, forming a strange, angular pattern. Julian leaned forward, studying the arrangement. “It’s the mark,” he whispered, awe and fear mingling in his voice.

A low vibration thrummed through the floor. The candles guttered, stretching the shadows into impossible shapes. From somewhere beneath them, a voice rose—soft and ancient, echoing through the bones of the warehouse.

August met Julian’s gaze. “We started something.”

Julian nodded, barely breathing. “Now we finish it.”

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back.

responses.text: These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. Every afternoon, she’d line them up on the faded quilt, her ragged bear at the center, the one with the missing ear and untied bow. She would serve them tea in chipped porcelain cups, pouring invisible liquid and whispering secrets to each in turn. When the world outside was too loud, she’d clutch the plush menagerie close and create kingdoms where no one could be hurt or left behind. Years later, unpacking boxes in her first apartment, she found them again—threadbare, faded, and smelling faintly of lavender and dust. She hesitated, hands trembling, before placing them on her new bed. Through heartbreaks, late-night phone calls, and the hollow ache of solitude, she’d return to them. They never answered, never complained, but she loved them anyway, fiercely and without expectation. In their silent, unchanging presence, she realized love didn’t require reciprocation—it required courage, tenderness, and the willingness to give, even when there was nothing in return but the soft comfort of memory.

These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. She would cradle the faded rabbit in her arms, tracing the stitches her grandmother once sewed, whispering secrets into its lopsided ear. Each night, as the wind shuddered through the thin walls and shadows crept across her ceiling, she would press her cheek against the bear’s patched fur and imagine it responding with a warmth all its own. She grew, her arms lengthening, her heart aching with new kinds of longing. The animals gathered dust on a high shelf, but she never let them go, not really. When love came—raw and sharp, sometimes silent—she recognized its shape. She’d learned to pour her affection into spaces that might never echo her back, to care for the silent and the still. On her loneliest nights, she’d return to the shelf, pull down the rabbit, and remember: love is not always returned, but it is always given. In her quiet room, surrounded by old friends, she learned to keep loving, even when the world could not love her back.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back.

responses.text: These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. Yet, each time she stumbled, she remembered the comfort of those silent companions: how she had loved them fiercely, never expecting anything in return. The world was full of things that could not love her back, but she chose to love anyway, mending what she could and letting the rest remain imperfect, hoping that, somewhere, her kindness softened the silence.

These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. She would arrange them in careful circles, giving each a name and a story, reading them tales and dressing them in scraps of fabric. They sat, mute and unblinking, their button eyes reflecting the gleam of her devotion. As she grew, the animals migrated to the back of her closet, but the lesson lingered. In college, she found herself drawn to lost causes and lonely souls, loving without ever asking if the feeling was returned. She learned to find beauty in the quiet presence of things and people, to give comfort where it was needed, and to cherish the bittersweet ache of loving unconditionally. Sometimes, on nights when the world felt vast and indifferent, she would find one of her old stuffed friends and remember that love, even unreciprocated, was always worth giving.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back.

responses.text: These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. When she was six, she declared the armchair in the attic their castle, draping it with scarves and old lace, anointing each plush creature with a name and a wish. The giraffe wore a crown of paperclips; the turtle, a superhero cape cut from her father’s old shirt. She confided her wildest hopes to them—of flying, of becoming invisible, of finding her missing mother. Sometimes, in the pale half-light, it seemed they listened. But mostly, they remained as they were: silent, steadfast, incapable of return. Years later, she would recognize that same ache in her chest when she fell for people whose hearts were locked away, or poured herself into causes that could not fill her back up. But still, she returned to the attic, brushing dust from her old friends, understanding finally that loving was not about being loved in return, but about holding space for possibility, even in a world of soft silence and unmoving glass eyes.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: He was still in the building.

responses.text: He was still in the building. The echo of his footsteps rebounded off the marble walls, each tap a metronome counting down to a moment he couldn’t predict. Outside, the city had faded into a velvet hush, streetlights flickering against the drizzle. He pressed the elevator button again, but the light stayed dark. His phone was dead—a casualty of his earlier panic. As he made his way back through the maze of corridors, he noticed strange details: a painting he swore hadn’t been there before, a door cracked open revealing a sliver of blue light. With each corner turned, the building seemed to shift, elongate, as if it were holding him. He tried to recall the floor plan, but memory failed him. The air grew thick with the scent of ozone, and somewhere above, a soft mechanical whirring began. He wasn’t sure if he was being watched or if he was simply losing track of time. He paused, hand on a cool brass doorknob, debating whether to turn it. Whatever was waiting, he knew one thing: he was not alone in the building.

He was still in the building. The clock on the wall had long since stopped ticking, and the fluorescent lights hummed overhead, flickering in protest of the late hour. Marcus pressed himself against the cool tile, heart pounding so loudly he was sure it would give him away. Beyond the security desk, a shadow moved—slow, deliberate, as if savoring the hunt. He clutched the small key in his palm, the one that was supposed to unlock the archives. The plan had seemed simple, but now the corridors seemed to stretch endlessly, each turn a new threat. He slid along the wall, straining to remember the map he’d studied for days. If he could just reach the stairwell, maybe he’d have a chance. But the footsteps grew louder, echoing in the emptiness. Marcus took a breath, steeled himself, and darted forward, praying the darkness would shield him. He had to know the truth hidden in the archives—even if it meant he might never leave the building at all.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: He was still in the building.

responses.text: He was still in the building. The alarms had long since quieted, leaving a suffocating silence in their wake. Dust motes floated lazily through the beams of moonlight spilling onto the cracked linoleum. Soren tried the main doors again, but they wouldn't budge. Instead, he wandered deeper, past offices abandoned in haste—coffee mugs half-drunk, chairs askew. He followed the faint sound of music, a haunting lullaby echoing from the basement. The melody grew louder as he descended, until he reached the old records room. There, in the flickering glow of a single desk lamp, sat a young girl humming to herself, surrounded by file boxes. She looked up, unafraid. "I've been waiting for you," she said, her eyes impossibly old. Soren hesitated, but something compelled him forward. He knew, somehow, that leaving the building was no longer an option—at least, not until he understood why he was the last one left.

He was still in the building. The fire exits were locked, and the main lobby was a maze of toppled chairs and overturned potted plants. Somewhere in the distance, a radio crackled with static, punctuated by bursts of frantic voices he couldn't quite make out. Daniel pressed himself against the cold marble column, trying to slow his breathing. He should've left when the others did, he thought, but curiosity—or maybe stubbornness—kept him searching for the source of the strange lights flickering behind the finance office. The walls pulsed with a faint, unnatural glow. As he crept closer, the air vibrated with a low hum, and he felt the hairs on his arms stand up. Whatever was happening here, Daniel realized, wasn't meant to be seen. But now that he was here, alone in the building's belly, he had no intention of turning back.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: He was still in the building.

responses.text: He was still in the building. The security cameras, all but one, had gone dark hours ago—except for the one outside the old records vault. Rohan pressed his back against the filing cabinets, listening to the dull thud of his own heartbeat and the distant, rhythmic squeak of a janitor’s cart. He gripped a faded envelope in his hand, the one marked only with a red X. The silence was heavy, punctuated by the occasional groan of aging pipes. As he crept down the corridor, memories surfaced of whispered office rumors: that at midnight, the building’s blueprints rearranged themselves, and doors led somewhere different each night. He found the elevator doors open, waiting for him, though he’d never pressed the button. With a swallow of dread and anticipation, he stepped inside. As the doors sealed shut, the numbers above flickered, then reversed, descending into floors Rohan never knew existed. He realized, too late, that leaving the building was never part of the plan—it was always about discovering what waited below.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Something inside her was healing at a rapid rate, not only because of this love stampede that had totally trampled her beneath its hooves.

responses.text:
Something inside her was healing at a rapid rate, not only because of this love stampede that had totally trampled her beneath its hooves. It was as if the chaos of affection had jostled loose all the old aches and pains she’d been carrying, scattering them like confetti in the wind. In the aftermath, she found herself standing in a quiet field, dazed and blinking under a sky that seemed impossibly blue. The world felt raw and new. She reached up, half-expecting to find bruises, but instead her fingertips met warmth, a subtle hum beneath her skin. 

Each day brought a new surprise: the way laughter bubbled up so easily during breakfast, how her hands trembled less while tying her shoes, the gentle ache in her chest replaced by a hopeful flutter. It was terrifying, but she let the tide of it sweep her along. With every step, she realized this love—wild, messy, all-consuming—was not just trampling her, but planting something vibrant in her wake. For the first time in years, she didn’t want the stampede to end.

Something inside her was healing at a rapid rate, not only because of this love stampede that had totally trampled her beneath its hooves. There was a peculiar magic in the way chaos had become a catalyst—her wounds, once stubborn and silent, now sang with the possibility of mending. She spent her days tracing the outlines of this upheaval, sometimes with trembling hands. The world had shifted; every glance, every shared silence with him, seemed to pulse with the energy of fresh beginnings.

She started to notice small things: how her laughter no longer sounded foreign, how her reflection seemed less like a stranger. The love stampede had left her breathless, but it had also left her lighter, as though the weight she’d carried for years had been scattered across the plains. Even in the quiet moments, when doubt threatened to seep in, she could feel new roots burrowing deep. She was not only surviving the stampede—she was growing, wild and uncontained, in its wake.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Something inside her was healing at a rapid rate, not only because of this love stampede that had totally trampled her beneath its hooves.

responses.text:

She began to seek out the small chaos—messy sandwiches eaten on the fire escape, impromptu dances in the rain, midnight stories whispered just to make each other giggle. The boundaries of her loneliness dissolved, replaced by something unruly and bright. She wasn’t sure if the love would last. But the stampede had done its work: it had shattered the shell she’d built around her heart, letting light and possibility flood in. Healing, she discovered, sometimes required being trampled first.

Something inside her was healing at a rapid rate, not only because of this love stampede that had totally trampled her beneath its hooves. prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Something inside her was healing at a rapid rate, not only because of this love stampede that had totally trampled her beneath its hooves.

responses.text:

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Without a goodbye.

responses.text: Without a goodbye, the city’s neon lights flickered into morning. Mara’s suitcase thumped down the stairwell, echoing in the silence of a life left behind. She paused at the threshold, keys cold in her palm, a single note pressed against the kitchen table—a page filled with ink, but empty of explanations. The taxi’s horn cut through dawn’s hush. From the backseat, Mara watched her apartment fade, windows dark and unblinking, the world blurring with each turn. She let herself mourn the words she’d never spoken, the apologies that would never be heard. In the airport’s anonymity, she surrendered her past to the conveyor belt, boarding a new life where no one knew her name. Sometimes, as the plane soared above sleeping suburbs, she wondered if silence could be a kindness, or if some doors, once closed, never truly stay shut. But above the clouds, Mara breathed in freedom, as weightless as the morning sun.

Without a goodbye, the clock in the hallway kept ticking. Its hands moved steadily, indifferent to the abruptness of his absence. Anna sat on the faded couch, clutching a mug that had long gone cold, replaying the morning’s silence. The door had closed softly—no angry words, no final glance. Only the faint scent of his cologne hovered in the air, mingling with the lavender from last night’s tea. She tried to recall if she’d missed a sign, some hint of departure in his eyes or the way he lingered at the window. Outside, the world unfolded as usual: dogs barked, buses hissed, children laughed. But within these walls, time warped, stretching out each second into a question without an answer. Days would pass, memories would rearrange themselves, and perhaps Anna would find solace in the quiet. For now, though, the only thing she truly understood was the echo of absence—how it says everything words never could.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Without a goodbye.

responses.text: Without a goodbye, Eliot slipped into the shadowed park, the city’s heartbeat muffled under a thick layer of fog. He moved carefully, feet barely making a sound on the dew-wet grass. Behind him, the apartment window still glowed faintly—a beacon he’d never return to. He carried nothing but an old photograph tucked into his coat pocket, its edges worn from years of indecision. There had been no confrontation, no tears, just a quiet decision that took root and grew in the silence of early morning. As dawn crept over the rooftops, Eliot reached the riverbank, where freight trains rumbled like distant thunder. He waited, breath frosting in the chill air, until the next train pulled in. He boarded an empty car, pressed the photograph to his chest, and let the city fade away. Somewhere down the tracks, beyond the reach of memory, Eliot hoped to begin again, even if his past lingered, unanswered, in the place he left behind.

Without a goodbye, the last light in the house winked out, leaving only the soft shuffle of footsteps across the old wooden floor. June paused at the threshold, her hand on the doorknob, listening for any sign that someone might wake and call her back. But the silence pressed in, thick and expectant. With a shaky breath, she stepped outside, closing the door gently behind her. The air was cool, scented with rain and possibility. She started down the road, her bag bumping against her hip, heart pounding with the fear and thrill of the unknown. As the town faded behind her, June resisted the urge to look back. She had no map, no destination—only the certainty that she could not stay. Somewhere, she hoped, a new beginning waited, shaped not by the farewells she hadn’t voiced, but by the steps she chose to take alone.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Without a goodbye.

responses.text: Without a goodbye, the garden gnomes watched as Lucien vanished before dawn, their painted faces frozen in silent witness. The kitchen clock hiccupped at 4:17 a.m., its pendulum swinging into a day that would unfold strangely without him. In the attic, a half-finished kite fluttered near an open window, string trailing like a question through the cool morning air. Lucien’s footsteps left no trace on the dew, but the dog—old Jasper—sat by the gate, nose pressed to the slats, sensing the shift. By noon, the neighbors would speculate: a new job, a secret lover, a nervous breakdown. Only the gnomes, the dog, and the wind knew the truth: Lucien had built wings of regret and hope, and flown them into the unknown. The town would heal, the grass would grow, and maybe, just maybe, the next rain would bring a letter, heavy with the scent of faraway oceans and dreams too wild for goodbyes.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty

responses.text: I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty haunted her on her return. He told me this as we sat watching the moon’s trembling reflection on the water, his hands twisting an old wool cap. In the faerie kingdom, he said, every leaf shone with dew like spun glass and the air was thick with music that made your heart ache. She had danced with beings whose laughter could shatter glass and whose tears brought sleep for a hundred years. When she came home, she could not bear the roughness of bread or the dullness of sunrise. The world was too gray, too slow. One morning, she walked into the sea, her pockets heavy with stones. The Manx man said that every June, on the night she vanished, the faeries leave a wreath of bluebells at his door. He never touches them, but lets them wither, a reminder that beauty can wound just as deeply as any nightmare. He looked at me, eyes hollow as driftwood. 'Some doors,' he whispered, 'should never be opened.'

I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty had nearly erased her memory of home. He told me the story with trembling lips, hands folded in his lap as the fire dwindled. When she returned, she was changed: her eyes held the wild gleam of starlit glens, her laughter rang with a music not meant for mortal ears. She wandered the moors at dusk, searching for a portal that would not open. She painted her walls with colors no one else could see, wept at sunsets for their dullness, and spoke to shadows that never answered. Her father tried to help, but the world’s edges were too blunt, its joys too faint. The last morning, he found her gone, a handful of bluebells on her pillow, and the faint scent of honey and moss lingering in the air. Sometimes, he said, he glimpses her on the cliffs at twilight, her hair streaming in the wind, looking back at a world that could never hold her again.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty

responses.text: I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty seared her soul.
